thread.section_title: newstribune.com stories: Mid-Missouri and National Sports
thread.title: Lincoln to host conference leader Indianapolis
thread.title_full: Lincoln to host conference leader Indianapolis

author: Adam Burns
title: Lincoln to host conference leader Indianapolis
text:
When asked to describe today’s matchup against the Indianapolis Greyhounds, Lincoln head coach Mike Jones called it a great opportunity, or a great challenge for his Lincoln Blue Tigers. 
“It’ll be about how we approach it,” Jones said. 
The Greyhounds will surely be a challenge for Lincoln, as they made the 370-mile trip to face the Blue Tigers in a matchup of teams on opposite sides of the conference standings. 
The Greyhounds (6-1, 4-0 Great Lakes Valley Conference) are the top dogs of the conference and on a five-game winning streak, while the Blue Tigers (1-6, 0-4) carry the weight of a six-game skid and sit alone at the bottom of the GLVC. 
“We have to go in with the mindset thinking one play at a time, one quarter at a time and one series at a time,” Jones said. “That’s not going to change, whether we have a six-game winning streak or a six-game losing streak.” 
The Blue Tigers are up against an Indianapolis team receiving votes in the AFCA Division II Coaches Poll. The 37 points have them positioned as the 27th-ranked team in the country. 
“They’re a very good team,” Jones said. “We were talking about as a team that this is a great game to get up for. They’re nationally ranked, they’ve only lost one game in three years in conference.” 
So how can Lincoln change its misfortunes against Indianapolis? Jones said the team needs to find a way to play a complete game and overcome adversity. 
“You still have to go play-by-play, and that’s what we’re not doing,” Jones said. “We’re not making plays on a consistent basis. We’ll put three or four plays together and then we’ll have a bad play. So, we just need to eliminate the bad plays and be more consistent.” 
Jones is looking forward to hosting a talented team coming off a long road trip. 
“They’re going to have a little bit of a bus lag, hopefully,” he said. “We have to play with emotion, play with enthusiasm and understand that this is the best team in our conference right now. So you want to see how you measure against the best in your conference, and I’m excited about playing them.” 
The Greyhounds like to run first, and they do so with back Andrew Walker, who has racked up 571 rushing yards and seven touchdowns. The sophomore is the second leading rusher in the GLVC behind Bubba Jenkins of Southern Baptist. 
“You have to figure out what phase of the game you can stop,” Jones said. “We know they want to run the ball. If they can run the football, they’re going to have you on your heels all game because they can run play-action, and they can drop back. We have got to be stout in stopping the run.” 
Indianapolis wide receiver Reece Horn has caused fits for GLVC defenses so far this season, as he leads the conference with 843 receiving yards. On top of that, Horn is second among active Division II players in career receiving yards with 3,009. The senior is 246 receiving yards away from topping the all-time Indianapolis receivers list. 
Throwing the ball to Horn is three-year starting quarterback Connor Barthel. Last season against the Blue Tigers, the two-time All-GLVC selection had almost as many touchdowns as incompletions when he converted 23-of-28 passes for four scores. 
Lincoln’s passing game, meanwhile, has a wide-receiver corps that has evolved into a balanced group. Senior quarterback Owen Jordan has spread it out to the junior trio of Darius Hicks, Bryson Winfrey and Delvon Rouser, who all rank in the top seven in the conference in receptions. Rouser has 38 catches for 441 yards, while Winfrey has 37 receptions for 317 yards. Hicks leads the Blue Tiger receivers with 468 yards on 35 catches. 
“(Jordan) does a good job including everybody,” Jones said. “As a quarterback, if you have a No. 1 receiver like Hicks or (Winfrey), sometimes you’ll lean on those guys. … We expect them to do well. Owen’s done a great job of getting the ball to those guys. That speaks volumes of a quarterback.” 
The Greyhounds don’t turn the ball over much. In fact, Indianapolis is tied for first in Division II for fewest giveaways with four. Prior to some stumbles in last week’s 26-20 win against Quincy, the Greyhounds had committed just one turnover. 
Indianapolis likes to create turnovers and turn them into points, as the Greyhounds are the GLVC scoring defense leaders. The Blue Tigers lead the league in turnovers with 19. Jones said his team will have to execute better this week than in past weeks to top the Greyhounds. 
“You look across the board and this is a veteran club, and you know we’re young,” he said. “It’s going to come down to us executing, sticking to what we’re doing, because Indianapolis is not going to change. They are going to be who they are.” 
The game is set to kick off at 2 p.m. at Dwight T. Reed Stadium. ﻿
